Absolutely! In addition to the Blue Mosque, there are several other famous Ottoman-era buildings that feature intricate calligraphy and pattern designs. Here are a few examples:

1) Topkapi Palace: The Topkapi Palace is a sprawling complex that served as the primary residence of the Ottoman sultans for almost four centuries. The palace features a wide range of architectural and artistic styles, including intricate calligraphy, patterned tile work, and elaborately carved stonework.

2) Suleymaniye Mosque: The Suleymaniye Mosque is one of the most impressive examples of Ottoman architecture, designed by the famous architect Mimar Sinan. The mosque features stunning calligraphy and tile work, including intricate patterns that draw on traditional Ottoman designs.

3) Dolmabahce Palace: The Dolmabahce Palace is another grand palace that served as the seat of the Ottoman Empire during the 19th century. The palace is famous for its opulent interiors and impressive collection of artwork and furnishings, including intricate calligraphy and patterned tile work.

4) Rüstem Pasha Mosque: The Rüstem Pasha Mosque is a small mosque located near the Spice Bazaar in Istanbul. The mosque is famous for its beautifully decorated interiors, which feature stunning examples of Ottoman-era tile work and calligraphy.

These are just a few examples of the many impressive buildings and structures that feature intricate calligraphy and pattern designs from the Ottoman era. Each building reflects the unique cultural and artistic traditions of the time, and serves as a reminder of the enduring beauty and significance of Islamic art and architecture.
